name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: That night we returned to the House floor--hours after the attack--to finish our hallowed work and certify the 2020 election. We sent a message to the world that nothing can come in the way of our Constitutional obligations and our dedication to American democracy.

name: John Garamendi

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: RT @SenMarkey: There is no greater example of waste in the nuclear weapons budget than the $264 billion plan for a new Ground-Based Strateg‚Ä¶

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: My amendment will strengthen our national security and save billions of tax-payer dollars. I hope my colleagues will join me in this critically important effort to address the modern nuclear arms race and prevent the unnecessary expenditure of billions of taxpayer dollars.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: But more fundamentally, our nuclear posture is centered on a principle of deterrence rather than dominance. Regardless of Chinese nuclear capabilities, our strategic forces are sufficient to deter a nuclear attack on the U.S. or its allies.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: The deployment of GBSD will not impact our deterrence calculus since it will not alter the overall numbers of ground-based ballistic missiles.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text:
Opponents will also claim GBSD is needed since China is rapidly expanding its ground-based silo
ICBMs. Even with China‚Äôs reported expansion of its nuclear forces, our arsenal still dwarfs China‚Äôs.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: Opponents of my amendment will falsely claim that GBSD is more cost-effective. A 2017 CBO report showed that it would cost $37 billion less to life extend the Minutelam III than developing and deploying the GBSD through 2036.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: GBSD would require billions of taxpayer dollars to be spent unnecessarily. It also precipitates a modern nuclear arms race and predicates our nuclear modernization efforts on a strategy of dominance rather than deterrence.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text:
In fact, under the current plan, many Minuteman III
missiles will need to be life extended through the mid-to-late 2030s while they are gradually replaced by the GBSD. My amendment simply pauses GBSD development for one year while @POTUS prepares his Nuclear Posture Review (NPR).

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: THREAD: Today, the House is voting on my #NDAA amendment to pause the development of the Ground Based Strategic Deterrent (#GBSD) missile program. The Air Force has said the Minuteman III missile, which GBSD would replace, could be life extended instead of being replaced.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: I just spoke on the House floor about my amendment to the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) that would pause the development of the Ground Based Strategic Deterrent (GBSD) program. You can watch my remarks below: https://t.co/Vm8d6DxOhg

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: Unionized workers earn 11% more than their counterparts without union representation. Union workers also have better health benefits and access to paid sick leave on average. It's time to allow more workers to have a say in their workplace and pass the PRO Act.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: Other provisions of the PRO Act would put an end to the gig economy exploitation of the independent contractor loophole. This loophole allows Lyft and Uber to pay fewer taxes, prevent their workers from unionizing and dodge labor protections.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: Currently, when corporations like Amazon are found in violation of labor law they face no punishment. The PRO Act would allow the NLRB to fine these corporations, levying increasingly heavy fines for repeat offenders, ending illegal union-busting and protecting workers‚Äô rights.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: The PRO Act is the boldest piece of pro-worker legislation in 80 years. On Labor Day it is important to support workers and discuss this vital legislation. I am a cosponsor of the PRO Act which will empower workers and protect their right to organize.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: Unions built America‚Äôs middle-class. Workplace safety, an 8 hour workday, and the minimum wage were all won through hard-fought campaigns by the Labor Movement. On this Labor Day we commemorate the successes of organized labor and recognize the need for continued progress. https://t.co/8swwiBT6Mw

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: President Biden has made the right decision to end a war that should have concluded years ago and not pass this conflict along to a fifth president. I appreciate his leadership and am firm in my commitment to help every U.S. citizen and Afghan ally return to safety today.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: I've served on the House Armed Services Committee for 11 years. I have received countless briefings on the situation in Afghanistan, led delegations to the region, and studied the conflict and history at length.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: Evacuation flights are moving steadily, and the work is being done to bring people to safety. My staff and I are also encouraging any constituent who has family in the region that needs to be brought to safety to contact my office at CA03.casework@mail.house.gov.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: Today, our focus is on evacuating U.S. citizens and Afghan allies from the region safely and as quickly as possible. President Biden is sending additional troops to facilitate the departure of Americans and allied civilian personnel to safety.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: We owe them a debt of gratitude and must recognize the work they‚Äôve done to abate the threat of terrorism to our homeland. We must always honor their service and sacrifice.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: This situation is difficult for American veterans and everyone who has spent the last 20 yrs in Afghanistan. Those who risked their lives and paid the ultimate cost for their service did so with dignity and honor while carrying out the policies and missions of four presidents.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: The Afghanistan government wasn‚Äôt overthrown‚Äîit simply disappeared. President Biden was clear that we would not stay and force American soldiers to nation-build and fight indefinitely.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: While the events that transpired over the last 3 days happened more precipitously than expected, they have confirmed that the decision to drawdown was the right one. Afghanistan‚Äôs political leadership fled the country, and its military collapsed without even attempting to fight.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text:
The latter would put thousands of additional American troops in harm‚Äôs way and thrust our nation into the third decade of conflict in Afghanistan. 

The President made the right decision.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: Those who were silent while the previous administration pursued a full withdrawal and are now castigating the current administration are coated in hypocrisy. President Biden was faced with the choice of following through on that agreement or redoubling our efforts to fight

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: If he had not made this decision, there would be no ceasefire. No agreement protecting our forces. No status quo of stability without casualties.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: When President Biden took office, there was a ceasefire agreement in place negotiated by President Trump and the Taliban. President Trump agreed to a full withdrawal of U.S. forces by May 1. President Biden extended this deadline until September.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: THREAD: President Biden has a consummate understanding of the history of Afghanistan. He considered every fact and contingency and made the correct decision to drawdown the U.S. presence in the region. He was not willing to pass this war on to a fifth president.

@MacTXPress, the top Republican on the committee, said ‚ÄúHe likes round numbers, so that's how $750 [billion] got there.‚Äù

So this is something to keep an eye on as we continue to work through the #FY20NDAA this evening.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: The President called for a $750 billion top-line even after 23 of 26 Republicans on the Armed Services Committee sent him a letter supporting the $733 billion funding level. Why did he do this? #FY20NDAA.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: Now we are expecting it to be a contentious issue during the markup. So what changed? Once again, the President threw a wrench into an issue with bipartisan support. The President did that here by asking for a higher top-line funding level. #FY20NDAA.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: It's the sum of every authorization we fund in the entire bill. Right now the top-line funding level is $733 billion--which is exactly what the DOD planned and asked for. Our friends on the other side of the aisle also agreed with that funding level: https://t.co/GoXEI73q5o

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: We are in another recess and will reconvene in a few moments. It gives me the time to highlight something that will likely come up throughout the hearing: the total funding level in this bill, otherwise known as the "top-line" funding level. #FY20NDAA.

tweet_text: The en bloc package has passed and my two bills have made it into the mark! This is a common method Reps use to move legislation. Attaching individual bills to much larger legislative packages, like the NDAA, gives those bills a greater chance of passing Congress. #FY20NDAA.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: We have included all other amendments with broad bipartisan support into the Intelligence and Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee mark through the en bloc process. We've voice voted the mark and are moving on to the next subcommittee's mark.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: In this instance it was because the amendment required a waiver from another committee to be considered, but the other committee did not grant the waiver.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: This amendment was withdrawn due to what's called a point of order. Points of order are prohibitions against certain types of legislation or congressional actions. These prohibitions are enforced when a Rep raises a point of order against legislation that may violate these rules

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: Now, as we work through the Intelligence and Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee markup, we have our first individual amendment that we will consider. When individual amendments like this are proposed the full committee debates it and oftentimes votes on it.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: Voice voting is the quickest way to vote on something because we don't have to tally each Rep's vote. It's typically used when there's broad consensus on a vote or issue. It is the right of any Rep to request a recorded vote even if a voice vote is proposed.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: En bloc is when we bundle noncontroversial amendments together and vote on them all at once. The Chair of the subcommittee provides an overview of the en bloc package before we vote on it.

name: John Garamendi
tweet_text: The language for the TAL has been amended and adopted. It was a very quick process for this subcommittee's mark because it had broad bipartisan support and noncontroversial amendments. Because of that, the committee adopted the amendments en bloc and voice voted the mark.
